They added so much over the years:

Expeditions & Mutations that gave endgame players real challenges and teamwork opportunities.

Mounts that completely transformed exploration and travel, with their own progression and personality.

Seasonal content and live events that brought the community together again and again.

Improved crafting and trading systems that gave every player a purpose, from blacksmiths to gatherers.

But what I‚Äôll remember most isn‚Äôt the loot, the grind, or the power levels ‚Äî it‚Äôs the people. The community truly made New World shine. I‚Äôve had countless laughs, epic battles, and heartfelt goodbyes across Aeternum. From my first fishing trip gone wrong to the last territory war where we all knew it might be our final one ‚Äî every moment mattered.

New World: Aeternum has been one of those games that pulls you in with its world and keeps you grinding, in the best way possible. It‚Äôs fun, addicting, and packed with more content than you might expect at first glance. There‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about how the game rewards effort, whether you‚Äôre crafting, gathering, questing, or exploring the wild corners of Aeternum. It can be grindy, yes, but that grind gives every achievement a sense of purpose.

One of the biggest highlights for me has been the mounts. They completely change how the world feels ‚Äî speeding across open fields, cutting through dense forests, or climbing up rugged hills never gets old. The attention to detail in mount animations and the way they interact with the terrain adds a level of immersion that feels surprisingly natural. Traveling used to be a bit of a chore in earlier versions, but mounts make exploration exciting again.

Then there‚Äôs Night Haven, a beautifully atmospheric zone that stands out as one of the game‚Äôs best additions. The lighting, the eerie glow of the flora, and the subtle background sounds all come together to create a setting that‚Äôs both mysterious and peaceful. It‚Äôs the kind of place that makes you slow down just to take it all in. The first time I entered Night Haven, I genuinely felt like I‚Äôd stepped into another world.

What also struck me is how some areas of Aeternum remind me of World of Warcraft. Not in a copycat way, but in that nostalgic, comforting sense of a vast fantasy world full of distinct biomes and hidden stories. The architecture, the color palettes, and the ambient sounds all bring back memories of exploring Azeroth for the first time. New World manages to capture that same spirit of discovery, where every hill or forest feels like it could hide something worth finding.

It‚Äôs bittersweet knowing the servers are closing. There‚Äôs a sadness that comes with seeing a game you‚Äôve invested time in reach its end. But that shouldn‚Äôt stop anyone from experiencing what makes New World special while it‚Äôs still around. Even in its final days, Aeternum offers adventure, challenge, and beauty.

If you‚Äôve ever loved MMORPGs that reward effort and exploration, don‚Äôt miss the chance to dive in before it‚Äôs gone. It‚Äôs a world worth remembering.

This review is partially in response to the announcement that the game will be shutting down.

To preface, I would like to say that I'm hardly New World's number one fan. I've had a lot to complain about the game up until this point, and even still have gripes that will never have the chance to be resolved.

I will don't want to dwell on what I don't like too much, because my gripes are, for the most part, personal preference. Off the top of my head, the monetization of the game was just flat out greedy. And the transmog system was very not good. Everything else, from the poor gearing to the simple combat, are just a matter of preference.

Now for what I think this game does well, or maybe even the best.

The weapon animations for a few specific weapons are just downright some of the coolest in any mmo I've played. The Void Gauntlet as a whole is definitely one of the coolest weapons in the game even if it wasn't my favorite.

While the gathering and crafting system had a number of things holding it back from being great, several were addressed relatively recently. And even if they never added the end point they were wanting crafting to have, it's still what I spent a good deal of my time in the game doing. Not the best crafting system, but not bad.

It also has one of the best fishing mini-games out of any mmo on the market. Which is an important part to any mmo.

And for my absolute favorite part of the game, the thing that kept me from uninstalling the game and had me coming back regularly just to partake in this simple, joyous activity. The instrument system. Not only is it just flat out fun to play the guitar hero-esque minigame, being able to invite people to join in to play different instruments for the full ensemble of a song is just phenomenal. And the songs themselves sound great, kinda wish a few were easier to find sheet music for. The fact you can give anyone listening a buff if they tip you a few gold pieces, as well as just getting the buff yourself, which is stronger the better you play. It's all just phenomenal. And if any other mmo looks at New World as anything but a failure, I hope they can at the very least see this mini-game and take inspiration to make something just as fun for their own game.

As I said, I'm nowhere near the biggest fan of New World. But I have zero issues saying that the game doesn't deserve to be shut down. It's had a loyal, kool-aid drinking playerbase for its entire lifetime. Sticking with the game through thick and thin. And even if a player doesn't like everything in the game, there's always something in the game to have fun with.

Honestly, I've tried so many MMOs. WoW, GW2, Neverwinter, ESO, FF14, Wizard 101, Pirate 101, Wakfu, Runescape, Albion, Black Desert, Toontown, Rift, Trove, Dofus, Vindictus, Tera, and probably more that have slipped my mind. None of them have hooked me and made the memories like New World has (Though Albion came close).

While the setting isn't your usual MMO fantasy, the uniqueness helps it stand out. The quests and story telling are great, the graphics stand above and beyond other MMOs, and very few games match the wonderful sound design. I could listen to people chop trees and mine ore for HOURS.

The combat is simple, but stands out from your usual tab-target MMOs in a way that feels good for both PvP and PvE. The Skill Grind is fun in no small part to the excellent visual and sound design I mentioned earlier. Dungeons, Raids, and other late game PvE content encourages teamwork and communication, feeling rewarding when you are successful. The PvP gamemodes are also rewarding, whether it be the minor success of a duel or 3v3 fight or the cheers of joy from winning a War or OPR.
